p: Hisashi Yamamoto (nonmember) received a B.S. degree in 1981, a M.S. degree in 1983, and a Dr. Eng. in 1996 in Industrial Engineering from Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan. He worked at Toshiba Corporation in Japan from 1983 to 1990, at the Department of Management systems at the Teikyo University of Science & Technology from 1990 to 1998, and at the Department of Production, Information and Systems Engineering at the Tokyo Metropolitan Institute of Technology from 1998 to 2005. Since April 2005, he has been with the Department of System Design at the Tokyo Metropolitan University where he is an Associate Professor. His research interests include reliability engineering, operations research, and applied statistics. He is an Editor of the Journal of The Reliability Engineering Association of Japan, and a member of JIMA, JSQC, SPEJ, and ORSJ.

Ming J. Zuo (Senior Member, IEEE) received his B.S. degree in Agricultural Engineering from Shandong Institute of Technology, China, in 1982; and his M.S. degree in 1986, and his Ph.D. in 1989 both in Industrial Engineering from Iowa State University, Ames, Iowa, U.S.A. He worked at the University of Windsor in Canada for a year in 1989. Since 1990, he has been with the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Alberta in Canada where he is currently a Professor. His research interests include system reliability modeling, manufacturing systems, and applied operations research. He is an Associate Editor of IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON RELIABILITY, and Department Editor of IIE Transactions on Quality and Reliability Engineering. He is also a senior member of IEEE and IIE.

Tomoaki Akiba (nonmember) received his B.S. degree in 1995 from Nishi-Tokyo University College of Science & Technology, his M.S. degree in 1997 from Teikyo University of Science & Technology, and his Dr. Eng. in 2004 in Industrial Engineering from Tokyo Metropolitan Institute of Technology, Japan. Since 1997, he has been with the Department of Information Management Engineering at the College of Industry & Technology where he is a Lecturer. His research interests include reliability engineering, and operations research. He is a member of the editorial board of the Journal of The Reliability Engineering Association of Japan; and a member of JIMA, and JSQC.

Zhigang Tian (nonmember) received the B.S. degree in 2000, and M.S. degree in 2003, both in mechanical engineering from Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China. He is currently working as a research assistant, and pursuing the Ph.D. degree at the Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Alberta, Canada. His research interests include reliability engineering, maintenance planning and optimization, neural networks, prediction, and fault diagnosis.

details.abstract: In this paper, we provide an algorithm for evaluating the system state distribution for any multi-state consecutive-k-out-of-n:G system including the decreasing multi-state G system, the increasing multi-state G system, and other G systems. We evaluated our proposed algorithms in terms of the orders of computation time, and memory requirement. Furthermore, we conducted a numerical experiment to determine the actual computation time. Our proposed algorithm is more effective for systems with a large n.

links.abstract: The consecutive-k-out-of-n:F and related systems have caught the attention of many researchers since the early 1980s. The studies of these systems lead to better understanding of the reliability of general series systems, In computation and structure. This paper is mainly a chronological survey of computing the reliability of these systems.

links.abstract: A reliability diagram with n components in sequence is called consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system if the system fails whenever k consecutive components are failed. This paper presents a recursive formula to compute the exact system reliability, and gives sharp upper and lower bounds for it.

links.abstract: The previous literature on consecutive-k-out-of-n: F systems gives recursive equations for the system reliability only for the special case when all component reliabilities are equal. This paper gives recursive equations for the more general case when the component reliabilities can be different from each other. Furthermore, reliabilities can be computed more quickly from these recursive equations than those previously given.
